DOC.HEAD: Nations Praise Havel's Election
DOC.TEXT: Both Communist and non-Communist leaders of Poland, the country at the vanguard of the East bloc's democratic revolution, joined in cheering Vaclav Havel's election as president of Czechoslovakia on Friday. Western European leaders hailed the move as another step in Czechoslovakia's march toward democracy. The Bush administration said the election of the playwright, once a jailed dissident, ``marks a fitting end to a year of astonishing change in Eastern Europe.'' Havel, an internationally acclaimed playwright and opposition leader, was elected in a unanimous vote of his nation's Parliament as the first non-Communist president of Czechoslovakia in 41 years. Solidarity leader Lech Walesa in Poland welcomed the choice of Havel ``with great joy'' and wished him strength in carrying out his new responsibilities, according to the official Polish PAP news agency. In his telegram, Walesa said: ``Czechoslovakia needs people like you. The duty of a continuation of the chosen path of new reforms will rest with them.'' Communist President Wojciech Jaruzelski and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a former activist in the Solidarity labor union, also sent cables of congratulations to Havel, PAP reported. Mazowiecki was elected as the East Bloc's first non-Cmmunist head of government on Aug. 24, paving the way for a wave of reform elsewhere in Eastern Europe. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany sent a telegram to Havel promising that West Germany is ready to support Czechoslovakia in its pursuit of reforms. ``The new Europe of freedom needs a democratic and dynamic Czechoslovakia,'' Kohl said. West German President Richard von Weizsaecker said in a message: ``Dialogue and cooperation should accompany us in the future emergence of a united Europe.'' Havel's first foreign visit, announced Friday, will be to East Germany and West Germany on Jan. 2. In London, a Foreign Office spokesman said of Havel's election: ``We greatly welcome it. His commitment to the ideals of democracy has been repeatedly and courageously demonstrated.'' ``We are confident that he will promote Czechoslovakia's peaceful transition towards a truly democratic society, a process in which Mr. Havel has already played a crucial part,'' the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. He described Havel's assumption of power as ``a momentous step in the postwar history of our continent.'' In Paris, President Francois Mitterrand also offered congratulations. ``Knowing the eminent role you have played in the struggle for reestablishment of democratic institutions in Czechoslovakia, I am convinced you will be able to carry out successfully the heavy responsibility confided in you,'' Mitterrand's telegram said. President Francesco Cossiga of Italy said: ``The Parliament's choice ... represents a symbolic stage in the glorious march that the peoples of the Czechoslovak republic have embarked on toward ever higher goals of freedom, democracy and political pluralism.'' In Texas on holiday, President Bush pledged U.S. support for the changes in Czechoslovakia. Bush said Havel's election ``is living proof of what Mr. Havel has called the `power of the powerless' to bring about peaceful democratic change,'' according to White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater.
